column1: UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT for the DISTRICT OF NEW JERSEYv. Arthur Lawrence ABRAMS.No. 75-487.

On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.
The petition for a writ of certiorari is denied.

column2: with whom Mr. Justice POWELL joins
column3: dissenting.

column1: The Court of Appeals has advanced the novel doctrine that when the federal court acts on a record made in state disciplinary proceedings the federal court's power to discipline a member of its bar in circumscribed by the scope of the penalty imposed by the state courts. It has always seemed clear to me that the federal courts have plenary power over the admission
column2: disbarment
column3: or discipline of attorneys who practice before them. See Cheatham
column4: The Reach of Federal Action Over the Profession of Law
column5: 18 Stan.L.Rev. 1288
column6: 1291-1292 (1966). The federal courts are not bound by the standards of professional conduct prescribed or enforced by the States any more than States are bound by federal action. A federal court may well determine that conduct found tolerable by another jurisdiction merits disbarment in federal court
column7: as our actions disciplining members of this Court's bar implicitly demonstrate. See
column10: 420 U.S. 918 (1975); In re Disbarment of Buttles
column11: 419 U.S. 1101 (1975); In re Disbarment of Mades
column12: 414 U.S. 1154 ( 1974). A federal court must apply state law in diversity cases
column13: but there is not the slightest reason to do so in judging the conduct of members of its own bar.

column1: I do not share the view that this is a subject not warranting the time for full briefing and argument here. Granting that the burdens of our calendar do not permit full review of all we might desire
column2: the issue here seems so

column1: clear that we could appropriately grant the writ and reverse the judgment summarily.

column1: Lyman A. MOORE v. State of ILLINOIS.No. 74-6464.
Supreme Court of the United States
On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Illinois.
The petition for a writ of certiorari is denied.
Mr. Justice STEWART filed a separate statement:
The petitioner's Illinois conviction for first-degree murder was upheld by a closely divided vote in this Court in 1972
column2: Moore v. Illinois
column3: 408 U.S. 786. Moore had there urged that the state prosecutor's failure to disclose certain exculpatory evidence violated the principles of Brady v. Maryland
column4: 373 U.S. 83. The Court's ruling that Brady had not been violated was based on its interpretation of testimony given in a state post-conviction hearing by a prosecution witness named Sanders.

column1: Mr. Justice DOUGLAS took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

Sanders had testified at Moore's trial that two days after the murder a person known to Sanders as 'Slick' had told Sanders that it was 'open season on bartenders' and had confessed that he had shot a bartender in Lansing
column2: a nearby town. (The victim of the murder for which Moore was prosecuted was a bartender in Lansing.) At the trial Sanders had also testified to the effect that it was Moore who had made these incriminating statements. In a pretrial statement not disclosed to the defense
column3: Sanders had told the police that he had first met Slick 'about six months ago' in a local tavern. Evidence adduced at the posttrial hearing proved that Sanders could not have met Moore then because Moore had been incarcerated in Leavenworth Penitentiary at the time
column4: and Sanders acknowledged that Moore thus could not have been the man he knew as 'Slick.' This Court viewed these posttrial revelations as indicating only that Sanders had misidentified Moore as 'Slick' but not as impeaching Sanders' trial testimony that it was Moore who had confessed to the shooting of a bartender in Lansing. Accordingly
column5: the Court concluded that

column1: 'Sanders' misidentification of Moore as Slick was not material to the issue of guilt.' 408 U.S.
column2: at 797. Four Justices in dissent interpreted Sanders' posttrial testimony as an acknowledgment that 'it was impossible that petitioner was the man with whom he had spoken' about the shooting of the bartender in Lansing. 408 U.S.
Sanders executed an affidavit stating that it was inded 'Slick
column3: ' and not Moore
column4: who had confessed to the shooting of the Lansing bartender. On the basis of this affidavit the petitioner again turned to the state courts in an effort to overturn his conviction. Over the strong dissent of Mr. Justice Schaefer
column5: those courts denied him relief on the ground that Sanders' affidavit lacked sufficient credibility. People v. Moore
column7: 327 N.E.2d 324. I do not quarrel with today's denial of Moore's petition for certiorari
column8: for we cannot from this vantage point intelligently reassess the state courts' determination of questions of credibility. I write only to point out that those questions will be fully amenable to reassessment in a federal habeas corpus proceeding. See Townsend v. Sain

column3: and respondent members of Penfield's Zoning

column12: a not-for-profit corporation among whose purposes is fostering action to alleviate the housing shortage for low and moderate income persons in the Rochester area; (2) several individual Rochester taxpayers; and (3) several Rochester area residents with low or moderate incomes who are also members of minority racial or ethnic groups -- and Rochester Home Builders Association (Home Builders)

column1: Held:  Whether the rules of standing are considered as aspects of the constitutional requirement that a plaintiff must make out a ""case or controversy"" within the meaning of Art. III
column2: or
column3: apart from such requirement
column4: as prudential limitations on the courts' role in resolving disputes involving ""generalized grievances"" or third parties' legal rights or interests
column5: none of the petitioners has met the threshold requirement of such rules that to have standing a complainant must clearly allege facts demonstrating that he is a proper party to invoke judicial resolution of the dispute and the exercise of the court's remedial powers.  Pp.  422 U. S. 498-518.

column1: (a) As to petitioner Rochester residents who assert standing as persons of low or moderate income and
column2: coincidentally
column3: as members of minority racial or ethnic groups
column4: the facts alleged fail to support an actionable causal relationship between Penfield's zoning practices and these petitioners' alleged injury.  A plaintiff who seeks to challenge exclusionary zoning practices must allege specific
column5: concrete facts demonstrating that such practices harm him
column6: and that he personally would benefit in a tangible way from the court's intervention.  Here
column7: these petitioners rely on little more than the remote possibility
column9: that their situation might have been better had respondents acted otherwise
column10: and might improve were the court to afford relief.  Pp.  422 U. S. 502-508.

column1: (b) With respect to petitioners who assert standing on the basis of their status as Rochester taxpayers
column2: claiming that they are suffering economic injury through increased taxes resulting from Penfield's zoning practices having forced Rochester to provide more tax-abated low  or moderate cost housing than it otherwise would have done
column3: the line of causation between Penfield's actions and such injury is not apparent.  But even assuming that these petitioners could establish that the zoning practices harm them
column4: the basis of their claim is that the practices violate the constitutional and statutory rights of third parties -- persons of low and moderate income who allegedly are excluded from Penfield.  Hence
column5: their claim falls squarely within the prudential standing rule that normally bars litigants from asserting the rights or legal interests of others in order to obtain relief from injury to themselves.  Pp.  422 U. S. 508-510.

column1: (c) Petitioner Metro-Act's claims to standing as a Rochester taxpayer and on behalf of its members who are Rochester taxpayers or persons of low or moderate income are precluded for the reasons applying to the denial of standing to the individual petitioner Rochester taxpayers and persons of low and moderate income.  In addition
column2: with respect to Metro-Act's claim to standing because 9% of its membership is composed of Penfield residents
column3: prudential considerations strongly counsel against according such residents or Metro-Act standing where the complaint is that they have been harmed indirectly by the exclusion of others
column5: in the absence of a showing of any exception allowing such a claim
column6: to raise the putative rights of third parties.  Trafficante v. Metropolitan Life Ins.

column2: which alleges no monetary injury to itself
column3: has no standing to claim damages on behalf of its members
column4: since whatever injury may have been suffered is peculiar to the individual member concerned
column5: thus requiring individualized proof of both the fact and extent of injury and individual awards. column5: or had any dealings with respondents.  With respect to the one exception
column6: this petitioner averred no basis for inferring that an earlier controversy between it and respondents remained a live

column1: Respondents requested the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) to make available Systems Worthiness Analysis Program (SWAP) Reports which consist of the FAA's analyses of the operation and maintenance performance of commercial airlines.  Section 1104 of the Federal Aviation Act of 1958 permits the FAA Administrator
column2: upon receiving an objection to public disclosure of information in a report
column3: to withhold disclosure when
column5: it would adversely affect the objecting party's interest and is not required in the public's interest.  The Administrator declined to make the reports available upon receiving an objection from the Air Transport Association
column6: which claimed that confidentiality was necessary to the effectiveness of the program.  Respondents sued in the District Court seeking
column8: the requested documents.  The District Court held that the documents were ""as a matter of law
column9: public and non-exempt"" within the meaning of the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA).  The Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment of the District Court ""insofar as appellants rely upon Exemption (3)"" of the FOIA.

column1: Held:  The SWAP Reports are exempt from public disclosure under Exemption 3 of the FOIA as being ""specifically exempted from disclosure by statute.""  Pp.  422 U. S. 261-267.
(a) Exemption 3 contains no ""built-in"" standard as do some of the exemptions under the FOIA
column2: and the language is sufficiently ambiguous to require resort to the legislative history.  That history reveals that Congress was ""aware of the necessity to deal expressly with inconsistent laws
column3: and
column4: as indicated in its committee report
column5: did not intend
column7: to modify the numerous statutes ""which restrict public access to specific Government records.""  Respondents can prevail only if the FOIA is read to repeal by implication all such statutes.  To interpret ""specific"" as used in such committee reference as meaning that Exemption 3 applies only to precisely named or described documents would be asking Congress to perform an impossible task

column1: and would imply that Congress had undertaken to reassess every delegation of authority to withhold information that it had made before the passage of the FOIA in 1966
column2: a task that the legislative history clearly shows it did not undertake.  Pp. 261-266.

column1: (b) The broad discretion vested by Congress in the FAA under  1104 to withhold information from the public is not necessarily inconsistent with Congress' intent in enacting the FOIA to replace the broad standard of the public disclosure section of the Administrative Procedure Act.  Congress could appropriately conclude that the public interest in air transport safety was better served by guaranteeing confidentiality of information necessary to secure from the airlines the maximum amount of information relevant to safety
column2: and Congress' wisdom in striking such a balance is not open to judicial scrutiny.  Pp.  422 U. S. 266-267.

column3: reversed.

column2: and the Birnbaum rule bars respondent from maintaining this suit.  Pp.  421 U. S. 731-755.

column4: and enforcement of the Internal Security Act of 1950
column5: began an inquiry into the various activities of respondent organization
column6: to determine whether they were potentially harmful to the morale of United States Armed Forces.  In connection with such inquiry
column7: it issued a subpoena duces tecum to the bank where the organization had an account
column8: ordering the bank to produce all records involving the account.  The organization and two of its members then brought an action against the Chairman
column11: and the bank to enjoin implementation of the subpoena on First Amendment grounds.  The District Court dismissed the action.  The Court of Appeals reversed

column1: Held:  The activities of the Senate Subcommittee
column2: the individual Senators
column3: and the Chief Counsel fall within the ""legitimate legislative sphere
column4: and since it is determined that such is the case
column5: those activities are protected by the absolute prohibition of the Speech or Debate Clause of the Constitution against being ""questioned in any other Place
column6: and hence are immune from judicial interference.  Pp.  421 U. S. 501-511.

column1: (a) The applicability of the Clause to private civil actions is supported by the absoluteness of the term ""shall not be questioned"" and the sweep of the term ""in any other Place.""  P.  421 U. S. 503.
(b) Issuance of subpoenas such as the one in question is a legitimate use by Congress of its power to investigate
column2: and the subpoena power may be exercised by a committee acting
column3: as here
column4: on behalf of one of the Houses.  Pp.  421 U. S. 503-505.

column1: (c) Inquiry into the sources of the funds used to carry on activities suspected by a subcommittee of Congress to have a potential
for undermining the morale of the Armed Forces is within the legitimate legislative sphere.  Pp.  421 U. S. 505-507.
(d) There is no distinction between the Subcommittee's Members and its Chief Counsel insofar as complete immunity from the issuance of the subpoena under the Speech or Debate Clause is concerned
column2: and since the Members are immune because the issuance of the subpoena is ""essential to legislating
column3: their aides share that immunity.  P.  421 U. S. 507.

column1: (e) The subpoena cannot be held subject to judicial questioning on the alleged ground that it works an invasion of respondents' privacy
column2: since it is ""essential to legislating.""  P.  421 U. S. 508.

column1: (f) Nor can the subpoena be held outside the protection of speech or debate immunity on the alleged ground that the motive of the investigation was improper
column2: since
column3: in determining the legitimacy of a congressional action
column4: the motives alleged to have prompted it are not to be considered.  Pp.  421 U. S. 508-509.

column1: (g) In view of the absolute terms of the speech or debate protection
column2: a mere allegation that First Amendment rights may be infringed by the subpoena does not warrant judicial interference.  Pp.  421 U. S. 509-511.

column5: and Huffman v. Pursue

column1: Nuisance proceedings were begun against appellants in Ohio courts on the theory that some of the books sold in a bookstore on premises owned by one appellant and leased by the others were obscene
column2: and that the bookstore was therefore a nuisance. The Ohio statutory scheme underlying these nuisance proceedings is outlined in Huffman v. Pursue

column1: Appellants filed suit in Federal District Court while the state proceedings were pending seeking injunctions against the state proceedings. The parties agreed not to go forward with the state court proceedings until the Federal District Court litigation was completed. The federal court refused to enjoin the state proceedings because it believed that Ohio could treat as a nuisance and close for a year a bookstore which sold some obscene materials
column2: without running afoul of the constitutional proscriptions against prior restraint of materials protected by the First Amendment.

column1: A similar issue was presented on the merits in Huffman
column2: supra. However
column3: the Court refused to pass on the merits
column4: because it believed that the federal court was barred from intervening in the state proceedings. The Court now remands this case for consideration in light of Huffman
column5: supra
column7: 419 U.S. 393. But I think it clear that even if Huffman was correctly decided
column13: it does not govern this case. Here
column14: the prosecuting authorities expressly agreed to submit to federal court jurisdiction
column15: and they do not in this Court argue that the District Court could not have enjoined the state proceedings even if it believed them unconstitutional. Thus
column16: any reliance on the principles of Younger v. Harris
column18: has been waived. See Sosna v. Iowa

column1: I need not reach the question of whether the Ohio scheme constitutes an impermissible prior restraint upon books never judicially determined to be obscene
column2: because I believe that suppression even of specific books adjudicated obscene in nuisance proceedings is unconstitutional.

column1: A Texas statute provides for the automatic dismissal of an appeal by a felony defendant if he escapes from custody pending the appeal
column2: except that the appeal will be reinstated if he voluntarily surrenders within 10 days of his escape
column3: or
column4: if he is under sentence of life imprisonment or death
column5: the appellate court
column7: may reinstate the appeal if he returns to custody within 30 days of his escape.

column1: Held:  The statute does not violate the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.

(a) It is not rendered unconstitutional by its separate treatment of prisoners under sentence of life imprisonment or death.  Texas can reasonably balance its concern with deterring escapes and encouraging surrenders with its alternative interest in allowing the validity of particularly severe sentences to be tested by appellate review.
(b) Nor is the statute rendered unconstitutional by its limiting the appeal-dismissal requirement to those prisoners with appeals pending at the time of their escape.  Texas
column2: as part of its policy to deter escapes
column3: is free to impose more severe sanctions on those prisoners whose escape is reasonably calculated to disrupt the very appellate process that they themselves have set in motion
column4: than it does on those who first escape
column5: return
column6: and then invoke the appellate process.

column2: reversed.

column1: Appellant's petition for divorce was dismissed by an Iowa trial court for lack of jurisdiction because she failed to meet the Iowa statutory requirement that a petitioner in a divorce action be a resident of the State for one year preceding the filing of the petition.  Appellant then brought a class action under Fed.Rule Civ.Proc. 23 in the Federal District Court against appellees State and state trial judge
column2: asserting that Iowa's durational residency requirement violated the Federal Constitution on equal protection and due process grounds and seeking injunctive and declaratory relief.  After certifying that appellant represented the class of persons residing in Iowa for less than a year who desired to initiate divorce actions
column3: the three-judge District Court upheld the constitutionality of the statute.

column1: 1. The fact that appellant had long since satisfied the durational residency requirement by the time the case reached this Court does not moot the case
column2: since the controversy remains very much alive for the class of unnamed persons whom she represents and who
column3: upon certification of the class action
column4: acquired a legal status separate from her asserted interest.  Dunn v. Blumstein

column2: as here
column3: the issue sought to be litigated escapes full appellate review at the behest of any single challenger
column4: the case does not inexorably become moot by the intervening resolution of the controversy as to the named plaintiffs.  P.  419 U. S. 401.

column1: (b) At the time the class action was certified
column2: appellant demonstrated a ""real and immediate"" threat of injury and belonged to the class that she sought to represent.  Pp.  419 U. S. 402-403.

column1: (c) The test of Rule 23(a) that the named representative in a class action ""fairly and adequately protect the interests of the class
column2: is met here
column3: where it is unlikely that segments of the class represented would have interests conflicting with appellant's
column4: and the interests of the class have been competently urged at each level of the proceeding.  P.  419 U. S. 403.

column1: 2. The Iowa durational residency requirement for divorce is not unconstitutional.  Pp.  419 U. S. 404-410.

(a) Such requirement is not unconstitutional on the alleged ground that it establishes two classes of persons and discriminates against those who have recently exercised their right to travel to Iowa.  Appellant was not irretrievably foreclosed from obtaining some part of what she sought
column2: and such requirement may reasonably be justified on grounds of the State's interest in requiring those seeking a divorce from its courts to be genuinely attached to the State
column3: as well as of the State's desire to insulate its divorce decrees from the likelihood of successful collateral attack.  Shapiro v. Thompson
column5: supra; Memorial Hospital v. Maricopa County

column1: (b) Nor does the durational residency requirement violate the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment on the asserted ground that it denies a litigant the opportunity to make an individualized showing of bona fide residence
column2: and thus bars access to the divorce courts.  Even if appellant could make an individualized showing of physical presence plus the intent to remain

column1: Appellant's petition for divorce was dismissed by an Iowa trial court for lack of jurisdiction because she failed to meet the Iowa statutory requirement that a petitioner in a divorce action be a resident of the State for one year preceding the filing of the petition.  Appellant then brought a class action under Fed.Rule Civ.Proc. 23 in the Federal District Court against appellees State and state trial judge
column2: asserting that Iowa's durational residency requirement violated the Federal Constitution on equal protection and due process grounds and seeking injunctive and declaratory relief.  After certifying that appellant represented the class of persons residing in Iowa for less than a year who desired to initiate divorce actions
column3: the three-judge District Court upheld the constitutionality of the statute.

column1: 1. The fact that appellant had long since satisfied the durational residency requirement by the time the case reached this Court does not moot the case
column2: since the controversy remains very much alive for the class of unnamed persons whom she represents and who
column3: upon certification of the class action
column4: acquired a legal status separate from her asserted interest.  Dunn v. Blumstein

column2: as here
column3: the issue sought to be litigated escapes full appellate review at the behest of any single challenger
column4: the case does not inexorably become moot by the intervening resolution of the controversy as to the named plaintiffs.  P.  419 U. S. 401.

column1: (b) At the time the class action was certified
column2: appellant demonstrated a ""real and immediate"" threat of injury and belonged to the class that she sought to represent.  Pp.  419 U. S. 402-403.

column1: (c) The test of Rule 23(a) that the named representative in a class action ""fairly and adequately protect the interests of the class
column2: is met here
column3: where it is unlikely that segments of the class represented would have interests conflicting with appellant's
column4: and the interests of the class have been competently urged at each level of the proceeding.  P.  419 U. S. 403.

column1: 2. The Iowa durational residency requirement for divorce is not unconstitutional.  Pp.  419 U. S. 404-410.

(a) Such requirement is not unconstitutional on the alleged ground that it establishes two classes of persons and discriminates against those who have recently exercised their right to travel to Iowa.  Appellant was not irretrievably foreclosed from obtaining some part of what she sought
column2: and such requirement may reasonably be justified on grounds of the State's interest in requiring those seeking a divorce from its courts to be genuinely attached to the State
column3: as well as of the State's desire to insulate its divorce decrees from the likelihood of successful collateral attack.  Shapiro v. Thompson
column5: supra; Memorial Hospital v. Maricopa County

column1: (b) Nor does the durational residency requirement violate the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment on the asserted ground that it denies a litigant the opportunity to make an individualized showing of bona fide residence

column5: unless
column6: within 10 days after notice that such charge has been filed
column7: the parties submit evidence that they have adjusted the dispute
column8: in which case or upon compliance with the Board's decision
column9: such charge shall be dismissed.  Pursuant to  10(k)
column10: a hearing was held before a hearing officer
column11: and subsequently the Board rendered a decision adverse to respondent
column12: which then indicated it would not comply therewith.  The Board's General Counsel thereafter issued a complaint on the unfair labor practice charge
column13: and at a trial examiner's hearing
column14: at which the General Counsel was represented by the same attorney who had been the hearing officer in the  10(k) proceeding
column15: the trial examiner concluded that respondent had violated  8(b)(4)(D)
column16: and the Board issued a cease and desist order.  The Court of Appeals
column17: on respondent's petition to set aside the order
column19: but refused to enforce the order
column21: because the  10(k) hearing officer had participated in both the  10(k) and the  8(b)(4)(D) proceedings
column22: the Board had not complied with the Administrative Procedure Act (APA)

column2: which prohibits commingling prosecutorial and adjudicatory functions in agency proceedings
column3: and generally applies to ""every case of adjudication required by statute to be determined on the record after opportunity for an agency hearing
column5: defining ""adjudication"" as ""agency process for the formulation of an order
column7: defining ""order"" as ""the whole or a part of a final disposition . . . of an agency in a matter other than rule making.""

column3: does not govern proceedings conducted under  10(k) of the NLRA.  Pp.  419 U. S. 441-448.

column3: and here the Board does not order anybody to do anything at the conclusion of the  10(k) proceeding.  Pp.  419 U. S. 441-444.

column1: (b) Nor is such determination ""agency process for the formulation of an order"" within the meaning of 5 U.S.C.  551(7).  Although important practical consequences in the  8(b)(4)(D) proceeding result from the Board's determination in the  10(k) proceeding

column5: the focus of the  8(b)(4)(D) proceeding.  The standard of proof is different
column6: and the inquiry in a  8(b)(4)(D) proceeding is whether the union engaged in forbidden conduct with a forbidden objective.  The proceedings are separate
column7: and the agency makes the determination in each of them.  Pp.  419 U. S. 444-448.
